Situation1: There is a scheduled family gathering on the calendar.
Expectation2: Represent clients effectively in legal proceedings
Situation2: They appear at a minor hearing where the stakes are relatively low
Story: I glanced at the calendar on my kitchen wall, the date circled in bright red marker: Saturday, family gathering at my daughter’s house. My grandchildren had been talking about it for weeks, planning games and asking if I’d bake my famous apple pie. I promised them I wouldn’t miss it for the world. But as I sipped my morning coffee, my phone buzzed—a reminder from the office. A last-minute hearing had been scheduled for the same afternoon. It was a minor case, nothing earth-shattering, but my client was anxious and counting on me to be there. I could hear my daughter’s voice in my head, “Mom, the kids are so excited to see you.” At the same time, I pictured my client’s worried face, trusting me to stand by them in court. My heart tugged in two directions, the warmth of family on one side, the weight of professional duty on the other. I sat at the kitchen table, torn, the clock ticking down to a choice I didn’t want to make.
